questions.question_text:
A company creates a Power Automate cloud flow for a Power Apps app.

The cloud flow must send a daily email that contains a list of year-to-date (YTD) totals.

You need to configure the flow.

Which feature should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The question is about how to configure the flow to execute actions on a list, not how to create a scheduled flow. So Loop (A) is the answer.

Selected Answer: A
A loop can be used to iterate over a list of YTD totals and perform actions for each item in the list

It cannot be a scheduled flow, because the Flow will be triggered from a canvas app as an instant flow.
The instant flow needs to loop through all entries, to check the date.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
A. Loop correct

comments.content: It says the flow already exists and you are configuring it. The loop will actually automatically be created when you add the variable from the look up records as it will need to run through all the found records and complete the action inside of the loop.

discussion.content: doesn t make sense, should just be scheduled flow

comments.content: Great question. I read 25 times and was wondering if I were the only one ...lol. Ohh G..

discussion.content: What in the world is a checklist record lol
Action Step both

comments.content: Action Step both
In action step I only have the option to start another process... hmm
correct thank you!
How could you prevent users from switching between stages by using Actions Step?
only from specific stages
where did it say Prevent?

discussion.content:
1. Action step: This feature can be used to control navigation within the business process flow, allowing users to move to the previous stage only from a specific stage.

2. Power Automate Flow: This feature can be used to automate the creation of checklist records when certain conditions are met within specific stages of the business process flow.
https://powerusers.microsoft.com/t5/Building-Power-Apps/Revert-to-previous-step-in-business-process-flow/td-p/893935

comments.content: which says to use a classic workflow.

discussion.content:

Basically, it is interesting, that microsoft did not (yet) offer this as a basic config functionality within BPF as a configration of a step! :-)

i can read a lot about javascripts online... to do this. PowerAutomate is the thing ms wants to sell. but right now this is is in preview.
I would create an optionset field on the record, sync the process status to this optionset field (synchroneously), then create a sync workflow that checks for this field stage if stage dose not equal... then stop workflow with message: not allowed to move back. I would make move back default and error out single backward moves. 
however: "while minimizing administrative and maintenance efforts" suggest an easy solution?!

1- Action Step 
2- Power Automate flow
Create checklist records in specific stages on demand is not an action step because action steps are used to perform an action without leaving the context of the record they are working on. Creating checklist records on demand requires a different workflow that can be triggered by a button or a condition. A Power Automate flow can be used to create checklist records on demand and add them to the business process flow.
action step both - based on what is written

ChatGPT says: 

Action Step 
Power Automate flow

to sum up the reasoning

Req.1: Classic workflow and Power Automate flow are not appropriate solutions for this scenario. Workflows are not designed to control the navigation of a business process flow, and Power Automate flows can be used to automate tasks but not to modify the behavior of a business process flow.

Req. 2: Overall, using Power Automate for this scenario can help automate the process of creating and completing checklists in specific stages of a business process flow, reducing administrative effort and increasing efficiency.
on exam march 2023
On exam 13 January 2023.

I believe the question is pointing towards a Business Process Flow which is one of the Power automate flows available. Within a business process flow you can move between stages. I do not know anything about checklist records. But the first would be Power automate flow. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customerengagement/on-premises/customize/create-business-process-flow?view=op-9-1
This question was part of the exam in Aug 2022

Classic Workflow, Action
Classic work flow runs as a stage event StageExit and StagEntry and can restrict or redirect the business flow to another stage.
On exam 20 April 2022.

Action steps are the list of action that you need to perform on each stage. For instance, verifying the customer, address, and so on before converting leads into opp. It has no connection to the flow. We can not go back from Deliver to lead as we have already processed payments. Ideally it should be Classic work flow and action. Correct if I am wrong.
Action Step both
On exam Jan 27, 2022
ANS IS CORRECT

Action, Action

Default BPF functionality and since BPF falls under Power Automate, I'm assuming this is correct

comments.content: Real-Time Workflow?

discussion.content: I cannot help but comment here that everybody seems to think that the Action Step will be on the same stage from which we need to prevent movement to next stage. First that assumption is convenient and wrong and second, they never talked about moving to next stage, they said to stop/allow movePrevious depending on current stages. The question is truly misleading as that is only possible via JS OnStageChange handler. Rest is fine with Action Step. But I do not know anyone who can stop the user from moving to any random previous stage just by clicking, while on any later stage in a BPF without Custom JS and just by WF/Action/PAF !!!

Action step can only be asociated to Classic workflow or Action.
I think actions are excluded with "minimizing administrative and maintenance efforts".
The associated workflow must have triggering entity of the base record (like Lead or Opportunity). It cannot have the BPF-entity as triggering entity. Therefore the classic workflow does not have access to the Active Stage in the BPF-entity (unless a customized lookup-relationship is established, whitch would add "administrative and maintenance efforts"). This is also applies with using directly the "Add workflow".
The classic workflow could be used to prevent stage changes, if triggering entity was the BPF-entity. However in that case there would be no need for the step in the business Process flow.
Only thing we have left is the Power Automate flow. It can be used to update the Activie Stage (of the BPF-entity) in the background. However, user has to refresh the form to see the changes.

Using async PowerAutomate to prevent realtime changes on the bpf....? I still doubt that but haven't tried that. What I know is that an action needs to be called. it does not have automatic triggers like a classic workflow. I would go with a classic realtime workflow on the BPF entity and trigger it on stage change, verify the transition and if not valid restrict change by throwing a "Canceled" stop workflow..... or am I wrong....? :/

answer is correct, you can manipulate stage ID using power automate and prevent returimng to previous one. this article discusses how to do it using classic flow but since power automate is recommended now so it should be the best answer https://d365demystified.com/2018/12/24/bpf-process-stage-name-not-populating-on-records-in-d365-v9-deprecated-and-workaround/

comments.content: The link you provided only shows how to populate bpf stage name as a custom text field, not set stage ID in the actual BPF.
Why classic workflow is dropped? They're intended to be used by business users, and I can't say that they are more complicated to maintain that PA Flow

discussion.content: Read this question several times. The key words are "reduce admin and maintenance efforts" - so this literally drop off the "classic workflow" option. Between Action Step and Power Automate, I feel both are correct but Action Step is more accurate. So the answers would be Action Step both

usually first answer should have been classic workflow, because we can run it sync and restrict conditional movement of Navigation.
But recently Power Automate have provided option in Dynamics to run asny flow but wait for it to finish, once flow finishes it can return success/failure status to BPF and based on Navigation can be restricted.
Ref Power automate article 
https://readyxrm.blog/2020/12/10/bpf-response/?utm_campaign=PP-Weekly&utm_medium=email&utm_source=Revue%20newsletter

comments.content: It is said that "reduce admin and maintenance efforts" - you need to disable workflow to edit it so it won't be a workflow for sure. You can edit power automate flow without turning it off

it doesn't seems like you explained. There isn't any returning response, you need to update the flow and refresh the page to see the change and since this is all happening async you cant prevent user to change steps. You need to use sync classic workflow for that
i agree.. :(

You have a business process flow.

You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

A company uses a model-driven app.

The company needs to automatically update the Status column in real time.

You need to configure this feature.

Solution: Create a flow that has an Update item action.

Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Answear is No
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/data-platform/configure-workflow-steps

comments.content: "You can update the row that the real-time workflow is running on, any of the rows linked to that row in an N:1 relationship, or any rows created by earlier steps."

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Yes, you're correct! If the workflow is configured as a real-time workflow (synchronous workflow) and includes an Update Record step, it can indeed meet the requirement to update the Status column in real time.

So, if the workflow is set up to run in real time, then:

A. Yes

This solution would meet the goal of automatically updating the Status column in real time.

Selected Answer: B
B. No

Creating a workflow with an Update Record step alone does not ensure that the Status column will be updated in real time. To achieve real-time updates, you need to configure a real-time workflow (synchronous workflow) instead of a background workflow (asynchronous workflow)12.

Real-time workflows run immediately and can update the Status column as soon as the triggering event occurs, ensuring the updates happen in real time.

Selected Answer: B
No. Need to use the "Change Status" step, not the Update Record step.
correct
(classic) workflows can by syc (aka 'real time') or async. they have not defined it. but defining it would kind of reveal the solution ;-)

Selected Answer: A
A workflow can be a background workflow or a real-time workflow
Answer is Correct

A company uses a model-driven app.

The company needs to automatically update the Status column in real time.

You need to configure this feature.

Solution: Create a flow that has an Update a row action.

Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The solution suggests creating a flow with an “Update a row” action. However, this action is typically used in scenarios where you want to update a specific row in a table (such as in a SharePoint list or a database table). It’s not directly related to real-time updates of a column within a model-driven app.
